Authors: Xiang Hui Zhao, Huan Li, Li Feng Zhou, Feng Mao Chen
Title:
Wilt of Acer negundo L. caused by Fusarium oxysporum in
China
Keywords: Acer negundo L., Fusarium oxysporum, Wilt
Abstract:
As a colorful-leafed ornamental maple tree, Acer negundo
L. is widely grown across China. In 2017, some trees in Pizhou, Jiangsu
Province showed symptoms of wilting. Leaves of diseased trees appeared
brown, wilted and wrinkled, the roots had rotted and the xylem had
become discolored. Investigations indicated that the disease spread
rapidly and that the infection rate was high. The outbreak period was
from July to August, which suggested that the high temperatures in
summer had no inhibitory effect on the occurrence of the disease. The
pathogenicity test showed that a fungus isolated from the discolored
vascular tissues at a high frequency, which was named An7, could lead to
100% mortality of healthy 2-year-old seedlings following inoculation.
Different sizes of conidia, chlamydospores and conidiophores were
observed. Molecular analysis of the partial sequences of the rDNA
internal transcribed spacer, intergenic spacer region and mitochondrial
small subuni, and the translation elongation factor 1-Î± was carried out
in combination with evaluation of morphological parameters, to achieve
reliable identification of the pathogen. The pathogen was identified on
morphological and molecular grounds as Fusarium oxysporum. To our
knowledge, this is the first report of F. oxysporum causing wilt on A.
negundo in China.
